data.title: British woman confessed to being a 'monster', her murder trial hears
data.meta_description: Jessica Davies told police she was a "monster" after she confessed to the drunken murder of a young Frenchman in 2007, a court has heard.
data.text:
Miss Davies, the 30-year-old niece of Quentin Davies, the Defence Minister, looked pale and drawn as she arrived at a court in Versailles, west of Paris, on the first day of her trial.

Dressed in jeans and a grey cardigan, her hair pulled back in a ponytail, she showed no emotion as the charge sheet was read out before the three judges and nine-member jury.

In November 2007, police arrived at her apartment in the chic Paris suburb of Saint-Germain-en-Laye and found the body of Olivier Mugnier who had been stabbed and whose throat had been slit, according to the indictment.

Miss Davies then told police: "I did it. I can't tell you why, but I did it. I am a monster", the court heard.

She had picked up Mugnier in a bar hours earlier and after taking him to her apartment, contacted police to say she had stabbed the 24-year-old man, justice officials said.

Miss Davies arrived at the courthouse in a police van and rushed into the courtroom where her parents were present as were the victim's family.

The trial is expected to last just two days, with a verdict due on Tuesday.

She faces a maximum sentence of 30 years in prison if convicted of voluntary homicide without premeditation.

Miss Davies, born in London to a British father and a French mother, was reportedly depressed after splitting up with her French boyfriend, with whom she had shared the one-bedroom flat for four years.

She was reported to have attempted suicide a few months before the murder of Mugnier.

On the Saturday night before Mugnier's death she was seen drinking pints of beer and shots of spirits in O'Sullivan's Irish pub in Saint-Germain-en-Laye.
